nodes.bodyText: This is not perfect, but it gets the job done. The need for these two suppliers and a function here is a bad signal I think, but it's the best I could come up with for now.
Does the metadata mappers map need to be a Supplier?
this annoys me too. I believe it has to, because the doc mapper can change in MapperService?

it is not fantastic that this is now moved to MapperService. On the other hand this code block required DocumentMapper as well as DocumentMapperParser (which is also one of the callers) and a bunch of other components that are easily available in MapperService and need to be carried around otherwise through DocumentMapperParser. So this is an ok compromise I thought. We may want to think about further cleanups around how we share the most common objects.

I wonder if we can make this neater by changing the signature of MetadataFieldMapper.getDefault()? Looking at the various implementations, we only need indexVersionCreated() and isIdFieldDataEnabled(), which we can abstract into a MetadataParseContext interface - that removes the reliance on DocumentMapperParser at least.

I tried this. Given the current state of things, I could replace the call to DocumentMapperParser with a Supplier. And even switching to a smaller context, the supplier would still be needed because idFieldDataEnabled is not carried anywhere. Moving back this code where it used to be, I would have to carry around the following:

Map<String, MetadataFieldMapper.TypeParser> metadataMapperParsers
Supplier<Mapper.TypeParser.ParserContext> parserContextSupplier
Function<String, Mapper> mapperLookup

especially the last one is odd, but the best I came up to not do this is what I did in this PR, expose a method from mapper service. What do you think?
This is definitely better.  I'm not completely happy with the metadata field builder abstractions, but maybe that will become clearer as we go on.
with the latest update, the third argument to lookup mappers would no longer be needed. Do you want to me to try and put this method back where it was, or are you ok with it being in MapperService?
Let's leave it in MapperService for now, we can always move it later if it gets too annoying.
Can we merge these two by just calling the function with null if there's no date formatter?

I think this can be simplified as follows:

if the existing mapper is null, iterate through mapperRegistry.getMetadataMapperParsers and call getDefault on each one.
if not, just return the metadata mappers from the existing mapper

The mixing and matching is unnecessary, because the index created version is fixed between the new mapper and the previous mapper, and so the set of metadata mappers for the two will be the same.
